Noemi Romano

//

Ingénieure en environnement spécialisée en SIG, analyse et visualisation de données

A new island in Venice lagoon

Lausanne, Visualizing future cities: Venice @ EPFL, Feb 2015 - Jun 2015

During the course Visualizing future cities: Venice @ EPFL we had the opportunity to rethink the Venice of the future. Mass tourism, souvenir shops, restaurants, but where is the city and where are the Venetians? Dating all the way back to the city's original charter, Venice is an artificial island. So, why not build a new artifical island and provide a new space for the Venetians and far away from the mass tourism?

In this project, my principal task was to visualize this new island in VR within the Oculus Rift and with the Google Street View images in the background.

Teacher: Isabella Pasqualini

In collaboration with: Laura Bornet

Technologies: Unity3D QGIS Oculus Rift Google Street View

Map of Venice: Positions of VR camera and new island
VR view

Venetian Arsenal 3D reconstruction

Venice & Lausanne, April 2016

The Venetian Arsenal has been for a long time the bulk of the Venetian republic's naval power and nowadays, a large number of shipyards and armories are disused. How could we revitalize this cultural heritage?

As a Geographic Information Systems student assistant, I introduced to students from Architecture, Environmental Engineering and Civil engineering data collection and digital modeling techniques, with an emphasis on data visualization and immersive VR with the Oculus Rift. Being employed at the same time as an application engineer intern by senseFly SA, I was able to survey a disused shipyard with a quadcopter drone and include the 3D reconstruction in the background of the students' VR projects.

Technologies: senseFly Albris Pix4D MapperUnity3D

Point cloud
3D façade
3D Points from 2D Keypoints Matches

Routine Transform

Lausanne, Pratiques Artistiques @ EPFL, Feb 2015 - Jun 2015

The main aim of this course was to make a video representing our routine at EPFL. We took pictures of our usual itineraries from home to EPFL and applied a Fourier Transform to these pictures.

This image processing technique is used to obtain the frequency domain of an image, while the initial image represents the spatial domain equivalent.

Teachers: Aloïs Godinat & Damian Navarro

In collaboration with: Briac Virey

Technologies: MATLAB iMovie

Frequency and spatial domains
© 2019 Noemi Romano
